I do it, I've seen my friends and family do it, Rachel even does it herself in this very video.

I'm not a body language analyst or anything, but it just seems really suspicious.
Like she's thinking "oh this is the most traumatic part of the story, so this is where my voice *should* be cracking, right?".
It just seems forced.

I can now more confidently believe that none of what happened was my fault, I was just being abused and manipulated and thats why I didn't think to leave or get help. comment:
You talk about red flags and how to spot them, but a I feel like a lot of people actually DO see the red flags and DO understand that they're bad but convince themselves that they can deal with them or that they can change them. It's how my last relationship was because I was young and didn't have any prior experience. I told myself that the issues I was having weren't that big a deal and that I could handle it because "that's what a good girlfriend does. She compromises." But, no. 

If there are issues, you need to recognize that and seriously sit down and think "IS this a big deal? Am I downplaying due to a fear of failure, being alone or simply because I care about this person?"
